heading: fed raises short-term rates
subheading: to make sure inflation does not rear its ugly head, the federal reserve raised a pair of short-term interest rates.
author: reuters
text: washington -- the federal reserve raised two short-term interest rates on tuesday to ensure inflation stays dormant in the buoyant us economy and signalled this may have been the last increase in borrowing costs for a while. the us central bank's decision takes the federal funds rate on overnight loans between banks to 5.5 percent from 5.25 percent, back to the level it was before the fed started a series of three rapid-fire rate cuts last year. to amplify its move, the fed also raised its discount rate on direct loans to banks to 5 percent from 4.75 percent."today's increase in the federal funds rate, together with the policy actions in june and august and the firming of conditions more generally in us financial markets over the course of the year, should markedly diminish the risk of inflation going forward," the fed said in a statement on the decision that had been awaited in us financial markets with an unusual degree of suspense.the fed said it had changed its monetary policy stance to neutral from a tightening bias, indicating it was not expecting to have to lift rates again in the near future.fed policymakers are next scheduled to discuss us borrowing costs at the next and final meeting of the federal open market committee this year on 21 december. but many economists doubt they will run the risk of adding to potential upheavals from the year 2000 computer problem, which would put off any rate rises until next year.copyright
